message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s Cushing disease was treated with bilateral adrenalectomy, which suggests a pituitary adenoma. The high ACTH levels and the bitemporal visual field defects suggest that the adenoma is large enough to cause pressure on the optic chiasm. Radiotherapy of the pituitary is the most appropriate next step in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient was previously diagnosed with Cushing disease, and the symptoms suggest recurrence. The next step in management is to perform radiotherapy of the pituitary to treat the recurrence. Administering metyrapone or reducing the dosage of glucocorticoids can lead to adrenal insufficiency. Resecting small cell lung carcinoma is not relevant to this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient was previously diagnosed with Cushing disease and underwent bilateral adrenalectomy, and now presents with hyperpigmentation, bitemporal visual field defects, and elevated ACTH levels. These symptoms suggest a pituitary tumor that is secreting ACTH. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is to perform radiotherapy of the pituitary to treat the tumor. Administering metyrapone, reducing dosage of glucocorticoids or resecting small cell lung carcinoma are not appropriate as they do not address the underlying cause of the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of Cushing disease, hyperpigmentation, and bitemporal visual field defects suggests a pituitary adenoma causing increased ACTH secretion. Radiotherapy of the pituitary is the standard treatment for Cushing disease recurrence after bilateral adrenalectomy. Metyrapone may be used as a diagnostic test, but is not appropriate as initial treatment. Reducing glucocorticoid dosage may worsen symptoms of Cushing disease. Resecting small cell lung carcinoma is not relevant to the management of Cushing disease recurrence.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and history of Cushing disease suggest a possibility of pituitary adenoma secreting ACTH (Cushing disease) or ectopic ACTH secretion. Metyrapone can be used to diagnose Cushing disease, but radiotherapy of the pituitary is the most appropriate next step in management to treat the possible pituitary adenoma. Reducing dosage of glucocorticoids should be done in consultation with an endocrinologist. Resecting a small cell lung carcinoma may be necessary if detected, but there is no indication of one based on the information in the question stem.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and history suggest possible recurrence of Cushing disease. The high ACTH concentration supports this suspicion. Radiotherapy of the pituitary can help manage a recurrence of Cushing disease. Administering metyrapone or reducing dosage of glucocorticoids may not be effective since the issue may be due to a recurrence of Cushing disease rather than medication management. Resecting small cell lung carcinoma is not relevant to the current presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and high ACTH concentration suggest that she has recurrent Cushing disease. Radiotherapy of the pituitary is a treatment option for recurrent Cushing disease. Metyrapone is a diagnostic agent for Cushing syndrome, not a treatment option. Reducing dosage of glucocorticoids is not appropriate because the patient requires cortisol replacement therapy after bilateral adrenalectomy. Resect small cell lung carcinoma is not appropriate because there is no evidence to suggest that she has lung cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of ACTH-secreting tumor and bitemporal visual field defects suggest a pituitary adenoma. Therefore, performing radiotherapy of the pituitary is the most appropriate next step in management. Metyrapone can be used to diagnose Cushing syndrome but not as a treatment. Glucocorticoid dosage reduction is not appropriate in this case. Resecting small cell lung carcinoma is not relevant to this patient's condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and high ACTH concentration suggests a recurrence of Cushing’s disease, which was previously treated with bilateral adrenalectomy. Radiotherapy of the pituitary can be used as a treatment. Metyrapone can also be used to diagnose Cushing’s syndrome, but it is not a treatment for Cushing’s disease. Reducing dosage of glucocorticoids is not appropriate since the patient is already on replacement therapy. Resecting small cell lung carcinoma is not indicated based on the information given.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and ACTH concentration suggest the presence of a pituitary tumor causing ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome. Radiotherapy of the pituitary is the most appropriate next step in management. Administering metyrapone or reducing dosage of glucocorticoids will not treat the underlying cause. Resecting small cell lung carcinoma is not relevant to this scenario.
